NL System Query: I want to learn how to play Quarto. Can you teach me?
User Response: Sure, anything you want to know?

NL System Query: Can you show me a win pattern in this game?
User Response: Assume you demonstrate this win condition
Comments: "win pattern" similar to "win configuration": too formal

NL System Query: In that case, let's call it win1, can we rotate it and still maintain the win condition?
User Response: Of course, you can rotate all pieces by 45 degrees and put them into the diagonal from bottom left to upper right. You can also rotate these pieces by 90 degrees and put them into the first column.
Comments: naming specific examples in the same way that values/objects are assigned to variables is too formal; "win condition" too formal; "rotate by so many degrees" too formal

NL System Query: And, can I shift those pieces to the uppermost row?
User Response: Yeah, you can do it, it will still be a win.
Comments: pretty natural: how about "place the pieces along the uppermost/top row" instead of "shift the pieces to the uppermost row"

NL System Query: Can you show me a new win pattern?
User Response: Assume you demonstrate this win condition
Comments: "win pattern" too formal: how about "can you show me a (new/different) win?" or "can you show me what a win looks like?" or "can you show me what winning Quarto looks like?"

NL System Query: For win1, is it a win because all pieces have the same color?
Comments: "win1" too formal; "all pieces" sounds more natural as "all the pieces"; "that is" should be "it is"

NL System Query: In this case, letâ€™s call it win2, can I shift pieces and still maintain the win?
User Response: You can move all pieces 1, 2, or 3 blocks up. Just make sure all of them are in the same row in each case.
Comments: "win2" too formal; "shift pieces" should be "shift the pieces"; "...1, 2, or 3 blocks up..." may be too formal

NL System Query: If I rotate all pieces in win1 by 90 degrees and put them in the first column, can it still be a win?
Comments: "rotate all pieces in win1 by 90 degrees" too formal, not necessarily expressing the desired meaning: even though the absolute and relative rotations correspond in this example, the natural language conveys a relative rotation when it should convey an absolute rotation

NL System Query: And, what if I add a new piece in the third column of uppermost row, can it still be a win pattern?
Comments: "of uppermost" should be "of the uppermost"; "win pattern" too formal; "can it..." better as "will it..."; "yeah, I think so" perhaps too uncertain for a formal affirmation

NL System Query: Can I rotate pieces and still maintain the win condition?
User Response: You can rotate those pieces by 45 degrees and put them in diagonal from bottom left to top right, or you can rotate them by 90 degrees and put in to the first column.
Comments: "win condition" too formal; "rotate by so many degrees" too formal; natural language conveys relative rotation when it should convey absolute rotation

NL System Query: Can you show me some other win formats?
User Response: Assume you demonstrate this win condition
Comments: "win format" a bit awkward-sounding, but an attempt at some variety

NL System Query: Let's go back to win2. Can it be a new win format if I shift all pieces to the third row?
Comments: "win format" a bit awkward-sounding; "it definitely can be" is not an affirmation, "it definitely is" is

NL System Query: So, can I do some shifts in win1 and maintain the win condition?
User Response: You can move all pieces to either the second row, the third row, or the uppermost row.
Comments: "can I do some shifts" a bit ambiguous; "win condition" too formal

NL System Query: That learning experience is so fruitful for me. Thank you so much.
User Response: No problem, I believe you will master this game one day.
Comments: "...is so fruitful for me" a bit awkward-sounding; "I believe you will master this game one day" a bit jarring, but hilarious
